New children's books for May 2018

Written by Sophie Green · Published Apr 30, 2018

Board books

On the Farm, by Axel Scheffler

Push, pull and slide rhyming board book from the illustrator of The Gruffalo.

â€œLittle ones can join in the fun on the farm by pulling out the sliders, jiggling the animals and making all the different noises! Quack along with the ducks, moo with the cows and neigh with the horses.â€

Peep Inside a Tree, by Anna Milbourne & Simona Dimitri

â€œPeep under leaves and behind branches to discover hibernating squirrels, creepy crawlies and more in this charming introduction to trees, filled with intricately cut flaps and holes to peep through. Find out what trees need to grow, what happens to a tree through the seasons, how long an oak tree can live for and much more.â€

Pop-up Things That Go! and Pop-up Ocean, by Ingela P. Arrhenius

Discover things that fly, things that zoom, things that float and things on the beach, on the waves and under the sea in these colourful pop-up books.

Babyâ€™s Very First Slide and See Night Time, by Fiona Watt & Stella Baggott

From the author of Thatâ€™s Not Myâ€¦. Pull the slider to see badgers playing, bats flying high in the sky and a panda going to sleep.

Bobâ€™s Blue Period, by Marion Deuchars

â€œWhen George plants a jellybean in his garden it grows into an enormous beanstalk and George is sure there must be a friendly giant at the top. As he climbs bravely up the beanstalk, higher and higher, George encounters a magical pixie, a stinky troll and gets stuck in a very sticky webâ€¦â€

My Daddy is a Silly Monkey, by Dianne Hofmeyr & Carol Thompson

â€œThis charming picture book for younger children portrays a day in the life of a dad and daughter in a single-parent home, as they get up, have breakfast, go to school, go swimming, make dinner and prepare for bedtime. Dad is a great big bear, a silly monkey, a crocodile, an octopus and, at bedtime, a scary monster for a little while - but in the end itâ€™s Daddy being Daddy that the little girl loves best.â€

This features on Booktrustâ€™s â€˜Best Picture Books for Dadsâ€™ list and is released in good time for Fathersâ€™ Day.

Space Tortoise, by Ross Montgomery & David Litchfield

â€œOnce, in an old rusty bin in an old rusty playground in an old empty park. there lived a little tortoise. But Tortoise is lonely. Heâ€™s never seen any other tortoises, and wonders where they could all be hiding.

â€œThen, one day, he looks up and the night sky, and sees a million blinking lights winking at him. â€˜That must be where the other tortoises are - at the top of the sky! I wish I could join them.â€™

â€œBut how can a little tortoise get to the top of the sky? And so begins a magical journey.â€

Youâ€™re Safe with Me, by Chitra Soundar & Poonam Mistry

â€œWhen the moon rises and the stars twinkle, it is bedtime for the baby animals of the Indian forest. But tonight, when the skies turn dark and the night grows stormy, the little ones canâ€™t sleep. Only Mama Elephant with her words of wisdom can reassure them â€˜youâ€™re safe with meâ€™.â€

A comforting bedtime read filled with intricate patterned illustrations, based on Indian textile design.

Gaspard the Fox, by Zeb Soanes & James Mayhew

First in a new series about urban fox and internet sensation Gaspard, by Radio 4 news and shipping forecast reader Zeb Soanes.

Thereâ€™s a Dragon in your Book, by Tom Fletcher & Greg Abbott

In the Mouth of the Wolf, by Michael Morpurgo & Barroux

The Burning Maze, by Rick Riordan

â€œLester Papadopoulos was once the glorious god Apollo - now heâ€™s an awkward (mortal) teenager stuck on Earth, out of favour with Zeus, and without his powers. The way out? A series of scary and dangerous trials, of course. â€œBut the Labyrinth holds a far more deadly threat - the third Roman emperor, part of a group of three Roman rulers bent on death and destruction. Barry Loser is the Best at Football NOT!, by Jim Smith

Rose Rivers, by Jacqueline Wilson

â€œRose Rivers lives in a beautiful house with her artist father, her difficult, fragile mother and her many siblings. â€œWhen a young girl, Clover Moon, joins the household as a nursemaid to Roseâ€™s troubled sister Beth, Rose finds a true friend for the first time and she starts to learn more about the world outside. Will Rose finally achieve her dreams? And will she be able to help Clover find her own dream?â€

Child I, by Steve Tasane

â€œA group of undocumented children with letters for names are stuck living in a refugee camp, with stories to tell but no papers to prove them. As they try to forge a new family amongst themselves, they also long to keep memories of their old identities alive. Will they be heard and believed? And what will happen to them if they arenâ€™t?â€

The Goat, by Anne Fleming

â€œA blind skateboarding writer, an old man who canâ€™t speak (and his wife), a smartly dressed non-hamster-owner, plus Kid and her parents, are all apparently sharing their Manhattan apartment building with a mountain goat.

â€œBut in all the wonders and marvels of New York City, who has time to see this impossible goat? How did the goat even get there? And is the goat really capable of something a little like magic?â€

Kat Wolfe Investigates, by Lauren St John

First in a new series about a petsitter and amateur detective.

â€œAfter a break-in at their London home, Kat Wolfe and her veterinary-surgeon mum decide itâ€™s time to move to the country. â€œWhen she starts a pet-sitting agency to make pocket money, her troubles escalate. The owner of her first client, an Amazon parrot, vanishes from his fortified, gadget-filled mansion, leaving a half-packed suitcase and a mysterious parcel. Ella on the Outside, by Cath Howe

â€œElla is the new girl at school. She doesnâ€™t know anyone and she doesnâ€™t have any friends. And she has a terrible secret.

â€œElla canâ€™t believe her luck when Lydia, the most popular girl in school, decides to be her new best friend - but what does Lydia really want? And what does it all have to do with Molly, the quiet, shy girl who wonâ€™t talk to anyone?â€

Aru Shah and the End of Time, by Roshani Chokshi

â€œTwelve-year-old Aru Shah has a tendency to stretch the truth in order to fit in at school. Whilst her classmates are jetting off to exotic locales, sheâ€™ll be at home, in the Museum of Ancient Indian Art and Culture where her mother works. â€œWhen Aruâ€™s schoolmates dare her to prove that the museumâ€™s Lamp of Bharata is cursed, she doesnâ€™t think thereâ€™s any harm in lighting it. Little does Aru know that lighting the lamp has dire consequences. She unwittingly frees the Sleeper, an ancient demon whose duty it is to awaken the God of Destruction. Her classmates and beloved mother are frozen in time, and, accompanied by a wise-cracking pigeon and her long-lost half-sister, itâ€™s up to Aru to save them.â€

This novel is full of action and Indian mythology and will appeal to fans of Rick Riordan.

How to Bee, by Bren MacDibble

â€œPeony lives with her sister and grandfather on a fruit farm outside the city. In a world where real bees are extinct, the quickest, bravest kids climb the fruit trees and pollinate the flowers by hand.

â€œAll Peony really wants is to be a bee. Life on the farm is a scrabble, but there is enough to eat and a place to sleep, and there is love. â€œIn Minecraft, danger lurks around every corner and youâ€™ll need powerful tools and equipment if you want to survive. Bonkers About Beetles, by Owen Davey

â€œDid you know that there are roughly 400,000 different species of beetles? These incredible creatures make up about 25% of all animals on our planet! Beetles are superbly adapted to life in various climates across the world, wherever trees and flowers are found.

â€œFrom the mighty Goliath beetle to the beautiful iridescent scarab beetle, this captivating and stunningly illustrated guide will teach you everything you need to know about these fascinating insects.â€

â€œDiscover all kinds of plants - from the hugest tree to the tiniest seed - in this fabulous follow-up to Creaturepedia.â€

The Big Book of the Blue, by Yuval Zommer

His wonderfully quirky illustrations show off all kinds of slippery, shimmery and surprising sea creatures, including sea turtles, whales, sharks, rays and seahorses.â€

The Bacteria Book: gross germs, vile viruses, and funky fungi, by Steve Mould

â€œMeet the bacteria, viruses, and other germs and microbes that are all around, but too small for us to see. Learn how they keep us and our world running.â€

â€œFrom Martin Luther Kingâ€™s dream, to Gandhiâ€™s protest, to Nelson Mandelaâ€™s struggle, discover how each of these people dedicated their lives to making the world a better place in their own unique, and peaceful, way.â€
